words.definition: A road vehicle with an engine, used for carrying a small number of people.
sentences: My dad drives his car to work every day.
We went on a long trip in our new car.
The red car is parked outside.

words.definition: A large road vehicle that carries many passengers along a fixed route.
sentences: I take the bus to school in the morning.
The bus stop is near my house.
Many people ride the bus to save money.

words.definition: A form of transport that runs on railway tracks, carrying passengers or goods.
sentences: We traveled by train to the mountains.
The train arrived on time at the station.
Children love to watch the big train go by.

words.definition: A vehicle with two wheels, propelled by pedals.
sentences: She rides her bicycle to the park.
Always wear a helmet when you ride a bicycle.
My new bicycle is blue.

words.definition: A two-wheeled vehicle with an engine.
sentences: He enjoys riding his motorcycle on weekends.
Motorcycles can be very fast.
The motorcycle parked next to the car.

words.definition: A large road vehicle used for carrying heavy goods.
sentences: The truck delivered furniture to our house.
Big trucks drive on the highway.
He drives a large truck for his job.

words.definition: A powered flying vehicle with fixed wings and a jet engine or propeller.
sentences: We flew in an airplane to visit my grandparents.
The airplane took off from the airport.
Airplanes can travel very long distances.

words.definition: A small vessel for traveling over water.
sentences: We went fishing in a small boat.
The boat sailed across the lake.
Many people enjoy going out on their boats.

words.definition: A large vessel that travels over water, especially the ocean.
sentences: The cargo ship carried many containers.
We saw a big cruise ship at the harbor.
The ship sailed to a faraway land.

words.definition: An underground railway system in a city.
sentences: I take the subway to get around the city quickly.
The subway station is always busy.
The subway trains run every few minutes.

words.definition: A car with a driver that you pay to take you somewhere.
sentences: We called a taxi to go to the airport.
The taxi driver was very friendly.
It's easier to get a taxi in the city center.

words.definition: A light two-wheeled open motor vehicle or a child's toy with a footboard and handlebars.
sentences: He rides an electric scooter to work.
My little sister got a new scooter for her birthday.
Scooters are good for short distances.

words.definition: A person walking rather than traveling in a vehicle.
sentences: Pedestrians should use the crosswalk.
The street was full of pedestrians.
Be careful when driving near pedestrians.

words.definition: A person who drives a vehicle.
sentences: The bus driver stopped at every stop.
She is a careful driver.
The race car driver won the competition.

words.definition: A person traveling in a vehicle but not driving it.
sentences: There were many passengers on the train.
The airplane can carry hundreds of passengers.
He was a passenger in his friend's car.

words.definition: A person who operates the flying controls of an aircraft.
sentences: The pilot announced our arrival time.
She dreams of becoming an airplane pilot.
The pilot landed the plane smoothly.

words.definition: The person in command of a ship or an aircraft.
sentences: The ship's captain guided it through the storm.
The captain welcomed us aboard.
He is the captain of the fishing boat.

words.definition: A person who collects fares on a bus or train, or who leads an orchestra.
sentences: The train conductor checked our tickets.
The bus conductor helped me find a seat.
He wants to be a music conductor someday.

words.definition: A piece of paper or card that allows you to travel on public transport.
sentences: I bought a train ticket to the city.
Show your ticket to the driver.
The airline tickets were expensive.

words.definition: A place where trains or buses stop for passengers.
sentences: We waited for the train at the station.
The bus station is very busy in the morning.
The police station is across the street.

words.definition: A place where aircraft regularly take off and land, with facilities for passengers.
sentences: Our flight departs from the main airport.
I arrived at the airport two hours early.
The airport has many shops and restaurants.

words.definition: A town or city with a harbor where ships load and unload.
sentences: The ship docked at the port.
Many goods arrive at the port by sea.
The port is a busy place for trade.

words.definition: A wide way leading from one place to another, especially one with a specially prepared surface.
sentences: The road was covered in snow.
Drive carefully on this winding road.
They built a new road to the beach.

words.definition: A public road in a city or town.
sentences: Our house is on a quiet street.
Children played in the street.
The streetlights came on at dusk.

words.definition: A main road, especially one connecting major towns or cities.
sentences: We drove on the highway to get there faster.
The highway was busy with traffic.
The speed limit on the highway is high.

words.definition: A structure carrying a road, path, railway, etc., across a river, road, or other obstacle.
sentences: The car drove over the long bridge.
The bridge connects the two sides of the city.
They built a new bridge across the river.

words.definition: An artificial underground passage, especially one built through a hill or under a river or city.
sentences: The train went through a dark tunnel.
The tunnel was very long.
They are building a new tunnel under the mountain.

words.definition: Vehicles moving on a road or public highway.
sentences: There was a lot of traffic on the way to work.
Traffic was heavy during rush hour.
The police officer directed traffic.

words.definition: To travel some distance regularly between one's home and place of work or study.
sentences: My dad has a long commute every day.
She commutes by train to the city.
His commute takes about an hour.

words.definition: An act of traveling from one place to another.
sentences: We had a long journey by car.
The train journey was very scenic.
Every journey begins with a single step.

words.definition: To go from one place to another, typically over a distance.
sentences: I love to travel to new countries.
They plan to travel around the world next year.
Travel can be very exciting.

words.definition: The place to which someone or something is going or being sent.
sentences: Our destination was a small village in the mountains.
We reached our destination after a long drive.
What is your final destination?

words.definition: A diagrammatic representation of an area of land or sea showing physical features, cities, roads, etc.
sentences: We used a map to find our way.
The treasure map showed hidden clues.
She drew a map to her house.

words.definition: A way or course taken in getting from a starting point to a destination.
sentences: We took the scenic route to avoid traffic.
What is the shortest route to the city center?
The bus follows a fixed route.

words.definition: A notice or indication that gives information, a warning, or an instruction.
sentences: The road sign showed the way to the airport.
Pay attention to the traffic signs.
There was a 'Stop' sign at the intersection.

words.definition: A traffic light, which controls the flow of traffic.
sentences: The car stopped at the red light.
Wait for the green light before crossing.
The traffic light changed to yellow.

words.definition: To cease moving or operating.
sentences: The bus will stop at the next corner.
Please stop the car here.
The train made an emergency stop.

words.definition: To move from one place to another.
sentences: The light turned green, so we could go.
Let's go for a walk.
The car started to go very fast.

words.definition: To bring a vehicle to a halt and leave it temporarily.
sentences: You can park your car in the parking lot.
I need to find a place to park.
Don't park here, it's a no-parking zone.

words.definition: A building or shed for housing a motor vehicle or vehicles.
sentences: My dad keeps his car in the garage.
The old garage needs repairs.
He built a new garage next to his house.

words.definition: Material such as coal, gas, or oil that is burned to produce heat or power.
sentences: We need to put more fuel in the car.
The airplane uses a special type of fuel.
Fuel prices have gone up recently.

words.definition: A common term for gasoline, a fuel for cars.
sentences: I need to fill up the car with gas.
The gas station is just around the corner.
We ran out of gas on the highway.

words.definition: Powered by electricity.
sentences: Electric cars are becoming more popular.
She rides an electric scooter.
The train uses electric power.

words.definition: A vehicle that uses both a gasoline engine and an electric motor.
sentences: Hybrid cars are more fuel-efficient.
My parents bought a new hybrid car.
Hybrid technology helps reduce pollution.

words.definition: A machine with moving parts that converts power into motion.
sentences: The car's engine made a strange noise.
The mechanic fixed the engine.
The airplane has powerful engines.

words.definition: A circular object that revolves on an axle and is fixed below a vehicle or other object to enable it to move easily over the ground.
sentences: The car has four wheels.
My bicycle has two wheels.
The wheel came off the toy car.

words.definition: A rubber covering, usually inflated, placed around the wheel of a vehicle.
sentences: My car has a flat tire.
You need to check the tire pressure.
The bicycle tire needs air.

words.definition: A device used for slowing or stopping a moving vehicle.
sentences: Press the brake pedal to slow down.
The car's brakes squeaked loudly.
Always check your bicycle brakes.

words.definition: A wheel that the driver turns to steer a vehicle.
sentences: He held the steering wheel tightly.
Learning to turn the steering wheel smoothly takes practice.
The steering wheel is on the left side in this car.

words.definition: A safety belt worn in a vehicle to prevent injury in a crash.
sentences: Always wear your seatbelt when driving.
The seatbelt clicked securely.
Make sure all passengers wear their seatbelts.

words.definition: A hard hat that protects the head, worn by motorcyclists, cyclists, etc.
sentences: He put on his helmet before riding the motorcycle.
Always wear a helmet when cycling.
The football player wore a protective helmet.

words.definition: The money a passenger pays for a journey on public transport.
sentences: The bus fare is two dollars.
How much is the train fare to London?
Children pay a reduced fare.

words.definition: A plan of times when things will happen, especially for public transport.
sentences: Check the train schedule for departure times.
The bus runs on a strict schedule.
Our travel schedule is very tight.

words.definition: The action of leaving, especially to start a journey.
sentences: Our flight departure was delayed by an hour.
We arrived at the airport two hours before departure.
The train's departure time is 10 AM.

words.definition: The action of reaching a destination.
sentences: We waited for their arrival at the station.
The flight's arrival time is 3 PM.
Their arrival was celebrated with cheers.

words.definition: A building at an airport or port where passengers arrive and depart.
sentences: Our flight is departing from Terminal 3.
The cruise ship terminal was very busy.
I'll meet you at the arrival terminal.

words.definition: A raised level surface alongside a railway track, where passengers get on and off trains.
sentences: The train is on Platform 5.
Wait behind the yellow line on the platform.
We stood on the platform waiting for the subway.

words.definition: An exit or entrance in an airport where passengers board or leave an aircraft.
sentences: Our flight is boarding at Gate B20.
Please proceed to your assigned gate.
The gate number was displayed on the screen.

words.definition: A strip of ground where aircraft take off and land.
sentences: The airplane sped down the runway.
The runway was clear for takeoff.
Birds on the runway caused a delay.

words.definition: A landing place for boats and ships.
sentences: The boat was tied to the dock.
We walked along the dock to see the ships.
The cargo was unloaded at the dock.

words.definition: A place on the coast where ships may find shelter.
sentences: Many boats were anchored in the harbor.
The city has a beautiful natural harbor.
We watched the ships leave the harbor.

words.definition: A machine used for transporting people or goods, especially on land.
sentences: A car is a type of vehicle.
Emergency vehicles have sirens.
He owns several vehicles.

words.definition: The system or means of conveying people or goods from one place to another.
sentences: Public transport is very convenient in the city.
We need better transport links to the airport.
The company specializes in goods transport.

words.definition: Buses, trains, and other forms of transport that are available to everyone and run on fixed routes.
sentences: I use public transport to save money and help the environment.
Public transport can be crowded during rush hour.
Many cities have excellent public transport systems.

words.definition: A car owned and used by an individual or family, not for public use.
sentences: We prefer to use our private car for long trips.
Having a private car gives you more flexibility.
Not everyone can afford a private car.

words.definition: To sit on and control a bicycle, motorcycle, or horse, or to be carried in a vehicle.
sentences: Do you want to ride my bicycle?
She enjoys a long ride on her horse.
We went for a ride in the countryside.

words.definition: To operate and control the direction and speed of a motor vehicle.
sentences: He learned to drive when he was 18.
I will drive you to the station.
It's a long drive to the coast.

words.definition: To move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn, never having both feet off the ground at once.
sentences: I like to walk to school on sunny days.
Let's go for a walk in the park.
It's a short walk from here to the shop.

words.definition: To travel through the air using an aircraft.
sentences: We will fly to Paris next month.
Birds can fly high in the sky.
He learned how to fly a small plane.

words.definition: To travel in a boat or ship, especially one powered by sails or an engine.
sentences: They sailed across the ocean.
We went for a sail on the lake.
The ship will sail at dawn.

words.definition: A holiday during which you travel on a ship or boat and visit a number of places.
sentences: They went on a cruise to the Caribbean.
The cruise ship was huge and luxurious.
I want to go on a world cruise someday.

words.definition: A journey or excursion, especially for pleasure.
sentences: We took a day trip to the beach.
Our family trip to the mountains was fun.
He planned a business trip to New York.

words.definition: A journey for pleasure in which several places are visited.
sentences: We went on a guided tour of the city.
The band is on a world tour.
She enjoyed the bus tour of the historical sites.

words.definition: The process or activity of accurately ascertaining one's position and planning and following a route.
sentences: GPS helps with car navigation.
Sailors need good navigation skills.
The app provides voice navigation.

words.definition: Global Positioning System, a satellite-based navigation system.
sentences: My phone has GPS to help me find places.
We used GPS to navigate through the forest.
The car's built-in GPS is very useful.

words.definition: A narrow road or a designated strip for vehicles on a road.
sentences: Stay in your lane while driving.
The bicycle lane is for cyclists only.
The highway has three lanes in each direction.

words.definition: A way out of a place or a road leading off a highway.
sentences: Take the next exit off the highway.
The emergency exit is clearly marked.
We missed our exit and had to turn around.

words.definition: A point or place of entering.
sentences: The entrance to the parking garage is on the left.
We met at the main entrance of the building.
The airport entrance was crowded.

words.definition: The rate at which someone or something is able to move or operate.
sentences: The car reached a high speed on the highway.
Drive at a safe speed.
The train travels at incredible speed.

words.definition: The maximum speed at which vehicles may legally travel on a particular stretch of road.
sentences: Always obey the speed limit.
The speed limit here is 50 miles per hour.
Driving over the speed limit is dangerous.

words.definition: A place on a road where pedestrians can cross safely.
sentences: Use the pedestrian crossing to cross the street.
The pedestrian crossing has traffic lights.
Always look both ways at a pedestrian crossing.

words.definition: A paved path for pedestrians at the side of a road.
sentences: Walk on the sidewalk, not in the street.
Children rode their bikes on the sidewalk.
The sidewalk was wet after the rain.

words.definition: A part of a road marked for pedestrians to cross.
sentences: Wait at the crosswalk for the light to change.
The crosswalk is painted with white lines.
Always use the crosswalk for safety.

words.definition: A long line of vehicles on a road that cannot move or can only move very slowly.
sentences: We were stuck in a huge traffic jam for an hour.
Traffic jams are common during rush hour.
I hate being in a traffic jam.

words.definition: A time during the day when traffic is heaviest.
sentences: Avoid traveling during rush hour if possible.
The trains are very crowded during rush hour.
Rush hour usually happens in the morning and evening.

words.definition: A designated place where a bus regularly stops to pick up and drop off passengers.
sentences: I waited for the bus at the bus stop.
The new bus stop has a shelter.
She missed her bus because she was late to the bus stop.

words.definition: A place where trains stop for passengers to get on or off.
sentences: We met at the train station.
The train station has many platforms.
He bought his ticket at the train station.

words.definition: A place where taxis wait for passengers.
sentences: You can find a taxi at the taxi stand outside the hotel.
There's a taxi stand near the airport exit.
We waited in line at the taxi stand.

words.definition: A service that allows you to rent a car for a period of time.
sentences: We used a car rental service for our vacation.
Car rental can be expensive.
He booked a car rental online.

words.definition: An arrangement in which a group of people share the use of one or more cars.
sentences: My friends and I use a car share service.
Car share can save money and reduce traffic.

words.definition: A service that arranges for people to share rides in private cars, often through a mobile app.
sentences: I use a ride-sharing app to get around at night.
Ride-sharing is a convenient way to travel.
Many people use ride-sharing services instead of taxis.

words.definition: A part of a road or a separate path designated for bicycles.
sentences: Always ride your bike in the bicycle lane.

The bicycle lane makes cycling safer.

words.definition: An area where vehicles are not allowed, only pedestrians.
sentences: The city center has a large pedestrian zone.

words.definition: An area for parking cars.
sentences: The parking lot was full.

words.definition: A multi-story building for parking cars.
sentences: We parked our car in the parking garage.

It's expensive to park in the city parking garage.

words.definition: A charge payable for permission to use a particular bridge or road.
sentences: We had to pay a toll to cross the bridge.

words.definition: A small building where tolls are collected.
sentences: The line at the toll booth was long.
Pay your toll at the toll booth.

words.definition: A circular intersection where traffic flows in one direction around a central island.
sentences: Take the third exit at the roundabout.
Roundabouts can be confusing at first.
The new roundabout improved traffic flow.

words.definition: A point where two or more roads meet or cross.
sentences: Be careful at busy intersections.
The accident happened at the intersection.
Traffic lights control the intersection.

words.definition: To change direction while moving.
sentences: Turn left at the next street.
The car made a sharp turn.
It's your turn to drive.

words.definition: In a direct line; not curving or bending.
sentences: Go straight ahead for two miles.
The road is straight for a long way.
Keep driving straight until you see the sign.

words.definition: Toward or on the side of the body that is to the west when one is facing north.
sentences: Turn left at the traffic light.
Keep to the left side of the road.
My house is on the left.

words.definition: Toward or on the side of the body that is to the east when one is facing north.
sentences: Turn right after the bridge.
The car is on your right.
Take the first right turn.

words.definition: To increase speed.
sentences: Press the pedal to accelerate the car.
The car accelerated quickly.
You need to accelerate to merge onto the highway.

words.definition: To reduce speed; slow down.
sentences: He had to decelerate quickly to avoid an accident.
The train decelerated as it approached the station.
Decelerate smoothly when coming to a stop.

words.definition: A gesture, sound, or action that conveys information or an instruction.
sentences: Always use your turn signal when changing lanes.
The traffic signal turned red.
He gave a hand signal to stop.

words.definition: A surface, typically glass coated with a metallic amalgam, which reflects a clear image.
sentences: Check your rearview mirror before changing lanes.
The side mirror was broken.
She adjusted the mirror to see better.

words.definition: The front window of a car or other vehicle.
sentences: The rain hit the windshield hard.
Clean your windshield for better visibility.
A crack appeared in the car's windshield.

words.definition: A device with a rubber blade that moves across a windshield to clear rain or snow.
sentences: Turn on the wipers during heavy rain.
The car's wipers were old and needed replacing.

words.definition: The enclosed storage space in the rear of a car.
sentences: Put the luggage in the car's trunk.
The trunk was full of groceries.
He opened the trunk to get his bag.

words.definition: The hinged cover over the engine of a motor vehicle.
sentences: The mechanic lifted the car's hood.
Smoke came out from under the hood.
He checked the engine under the hood.

words.definition: A horizontal bar at the front or rear of a motor vehicle to absorb impact in a collision.
sentences: The car had a dent in its front bumper.

The bumper protects the car in small crashes.

words.definition: A powerful light on the front of a motor vehicle or bicycle.
sentences: Turn on your headlights when it's dark.

The headlights lit up the road ahead.

words.definition: A red light on the rear of a motor vehicle or bicycle.
sentences: The car's taillights glowed in the fog.
Make sure your taillights are working.
He saw the red taillights in the distance.

words.definition: The waste gases from an engine, or the system through which they are expelled.
sentences: Black smoke came from the car's exhaust pipe.
The exhaust system needed repairs.
Car exhaust can pollute the air.

words.definition: A thing made or used for sitting on.
sentences: Take a seat in the back of the car.
The bus seats were comfortable.
He adjusted his car seat.

words.definition: A mechanism for transmitting motion, especially a toothed wheel.
sentences: He shifted into a higher gear.
The car has five forward gears.
Learning to change gears takes practice.

words.definition: A pedal in a car that disengages the engine from the gearbox.
sentences: Press the clutch before changing gears.
Learning to use the clutch smoothly is tricky.
He accidentally stalled the car by releasing the clutch too fast.

words.definition: A foot pedal that controls the speed of a vehicle's engine.
sentences: Press the accelerator to go faster.
He pushed the accelerator to the floor.
The car responded quickly to the accelerator.

words.definition: A foot pedal that operates the brakes of a vehicle.
sentences: He pressed the brake pedal firmly.
The brake pedal felt soft.
Always keep your foot near the brake pedal.

words.definition: A device on a vehicle for sounding a warning.
sentences: He honked the car's horn to get attention.
Don't use your horn unnecessarily.
The truck's horn was very loud.

words.definition: A device that makes a loud, wailing sound, used as a signal or warning.
sentences: We heard the police siren in the distance.
The ambulance siren was very loud.
The fire truck rushed by with its siren blaring.

words.definition: A vehicle used for emergency services, such as ambulances, fire trucks, and police cars.
sentences: Make way for emergency vehicles.
Emergency vehicles have special lights and sirens.
The road was cleared for the emergency vehicle.

words.definition: A vehicle equipped for carrying sick or injured people.
sentences: The ambulance rushed to the scene of the accident.
We heard the ambulance siren approaching.
The paramedics arrived in an ambulance.

words.definition: A vehicle carrying firefighters and equipment for fighting large fires.
sentences: The fire truck arrived quickly at the burning building.
Children love to see a fire truck up close.
The fire truck has a long ladder.

words.definition: A car used by police officers.
sentences: The police car patrolled the streets.
We saw a police car with its lights flashing.
The police car stopped next to the broken-down vehicle.

words.definition: The parallel steel rails on which trains run.
sentences: Never walk on the train tracks.
The train tracks stretched into the distance.
The train moved smoothly along the tracks.

words.definition: A track made of steel rails along which trains run.
sentences: The railway line connects many towns.
He works for the national railway company.
The railway runs through the countryside.

words.definition: A station for an underground railway system.
sentences: We met at the subway station entrance.
The subway station was very crowded.
You can catch the train at the nearest subway station.

words.definition: A boat or ship for conveying passengers and goods, especially over a relatively short distance and as a regular service.
sentences: We took the ferry across the river.
The ferry can carry cars and trucks.
The ferry ride was very pleasant.

words.definition: A ship that carries goods rather than passengers.
sentences: The cargo ship transported goods across the ocean.
Many products arrive by cargo ship.
The cargo ship was loaded with containers.

words.definition: A boat propelled by sails.
sentences: They went for a ride in their sailboat.
The sailboat glided smoothly on the water.
He learned to sail a sailboat.

words.definition: An aircraft powered by jet engines.
sentences: The fighter jet flew very fast.
We saw a commercial jet flying overhead.
Jet travel is very common now.

words.definition: An aircraft that gets its lift from rotors rotating on a vertical axis.
sentences: The helicopter landed on the roof of the hospital.

words.definition: A large balloon with a basket underneath, propelled by heated air.
sentences: We went on a hot air balloon ride at sunrise.
Hot air balloons offer amazing views.
The colorful hot air balloon floated in the sky.

words.definition: A vehicle used for travel in outer space.
sentences: Astronauts travel in a spaceship.
The spaceship launched into orbit.
Children often dream of flying in a spaceship.

words.definition: A person who is trained to travel in a spacecraft.
sentences: The astronaut walked on the moon.
She wants to become an astronaut.

words.definition: A person who serves passengers on an aircraft.
sentences: The flight attendant offered us drinks.
She works as a flight attendant.
The flight attendant showed us the safety procedures.

words.definition: A place at an airport or station where tickets are sold or checked.
sentences: Go to the ticket counter to check in for your flight.

He bought his train ticket at the ticket counter.

words.definition: The area in an airport where arriving passengers collect their luggage.
sentences: We waited at baggage claim for our suitcases.

words.definition: An inspection carried out to ensure safety and prevent unauthorized access.
sentences: You need to go through a security check at the airport.

words.definition: A pass that allows you to board a ship or aircraft.
sentences: Show your boarding pass at the gate.

words.definition: An official document issued by a government, certifying the holder's identity and citizenship, and entitling them to travel abroad.
sentences: You need a passport to travel internationally.

words.definition: An endorsement on a passport indicating that the holder is allowed to enter, leave, or stay for a specified period in a country.
sentences: You might need a visa to visit that country.
She applied for a tourist visa.

words.definition: The official department that collects duties on goods entering and leaving a country.
sentences: We had to declare our goods at customs.
The customs officer checked our bags.
Passing through customs can take time.

words.definition: Suitcases or other bags used for packing personal belongings when traveling.
sentences: Please place your luggage in the overhead bin.

words.definition: A bag with shoulder straps, carried on the back.
sentences: I packed my clothes in my backpack for the hike.
She carries her books in a backpack.
His backpack was heavy.

words.definition: A rectangular case with a handle, used for carrying clothes and other possessions when traveling.
sentences: I packed my suitcase for the vacation.
The suitcase had wheels, making it easy to pull.
He opened his suitcase to unpack.

words.definition: An enclosed storage space above the seats in an aircraft or bus.
sentences: Place your small bag in the overhead bin.
The overhead bin was full.
He struggled to close the overhead bin.

words.definition: A passage between rows of seats in a church, theater, airplane, or train.
sentences: I prefer an aisle seat on the airplane.
Walk down the aisle to find your seat.
The flight attendant walked down the aisle.

words.definition: A seat next to a window in a vehicle or aircraft.
sentences: She always asks for a window seat to see the view.

words.definition: A seat between two other seats in a row, especially on an airplane.
sentences: No one likes to get the middle seat on a long flight.

words.definition: Violent or unsteady movement of air or water, or some other fluid.

words.definition: An instrument containing a magnetized pointer that shows the direction of magnetic north.

sentences: We took a direct flight to our destination.
Direct flights are usually more expensive.
It was a direct flight, so we arrived quickly.

words.definition: A flight that travels from its departure airport to its destination airport without any intermediate stops.
sentences: The non-stop flight to Tokyo was 12 hours long.
She prefers non-stop flights to avoid layovers.
Finding a non-stop flight can be challenging.

words.definition: A period of rest or waiting between two stages of a journey.
sentences: We had a three-hour layover in Dubai.
A long layover can be tiring.
He used his layover to explore the airport.

words.definition: An aircraft engine in which a turbine drives a propeller.
sentences: Small regional planes often use turboprop engines.
The turboprop aircraft is good for short flights.
You can hear the distinct sound of a turboprop.

words.definition: An engine that generates a powerful thrust by expelling a jet of fluid.
sentences: Modern airplanes use powerful jet engines.
The jet engine roared during takeoff.
Jet engines are very efficient for high speeds.

words.definition: The compartment for the pilot and co-pilot in an aircraft.
sentences: The pilot sat in the cockpit.
Children often dream of seeing the cockpit.
The cockpit has many controls and displays.

words.definition: The main body of an aircraft.
sentences: The fuselage of the airplane is very long.
The fuselage holds the passengers and cargo.
Engineers designed a new fuselage shape.

words.definition: A main lateral appendage of an aircraft, providing lift.
sentences: The airplane's wings are very strong.
He sat by the window and looked at the wing.
Birds use their wings to fly.

words.definition: The rear part of an aircraft.
sentences: The airplane's tail has the airline's logo.
The tail helps stabilize the aircraft.
He saw the tail of the plane disappearing into the clouds.

words.definition: A mechanical device for propelling a boat or aircraft, consisting of a revolving shaft with blades.
sentences: The small plane had a large propeller.
The propeller spun rapidly.
Propellers push the air or water.

words.definition: A person who manages the flow of aircraft in and out of airports and through airspace.
sentences: The air traffic controller guided the planes safely.
Air traffic controllers have a very important job.
She dreams of becoming an air traffic controller.

words.definition: The personnel who service an aircraft on the ground.
sentences: The ground crew prepared the plane for takeoff.
The ground crew loaded the luggage.
He works as part of the ground crew.

words.definition: The distance an aircraft travels along the runway before becoming airborne.
sentences: The takeoff roll was smooth and quick.
The plane needed a long takeoff roll.
He felt the acceleration during the takeoff roll.

words.definition: The undercarriage of an aircraft, including the wheels or floats, used for landing and takeoff.
sentences: The pilot lowered the landing gear before landing.
The landing gear retracted after takeoff.
He checked the landing gear before the flight.

words.definition: The route taken by an aircraft.
sentences: The airplane followed its designated flight path.
The flight path took us over the mountains.
Air traffic control monitors the flight path.

words.definition: Transported by air; in the air.
sentences: The plane became airborne quickly.
Once airborne, the flight was smooth.
The helicopter was airborne in minutes.

words.definition: To leave a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle.
sentences: Passengers began to disembark after the plane landed.
We disembarked from the ferry at the port.
It took a while for everyone to disembark.

words.definition: To go on board a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle for a journey.
sentences: We will embark on our cruise at 4 PM.
Passengers were asked to embark at Gate 7.
He was excited to embark on his adventure.

words.definition: A long journey by sea or in space.
sentences: The ship embarked on a long voyage across the ocean.
The voyage to the moon took several days.
It was a memorable voyage.

words.definition: A journey or voyage undertaken by a group of people with a particular purpose, especially of exploration, research, or war.
sentences: They went on an expedition to the Amazon rainforest.
The scientific expedition discovered new species.
He led a climbing expedition to Mount Everest.
